items.title: Empty string keyword results in NestingError
items.body:
In my Django configuration I define a [root logger](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.getLogger):

```python
{
    "LOGGING": {
        "version": 1,
        "disable_existing_loggers": False,
        "formatters": {},
        "filters": {},
        "handlers": {},
        "loggers": {
            "": {},  # The root logger
            "django": {},
            "celery": {},
        },
    }
}
```
When I :
```python
config = ConfigObj()
config.filename = config_path
config.indent_type = "    "
config.interpolation = False
config.write()
```

the result is like that:

```ini
[LOGGING]
    [[formatters]]
    [[filters]]
    [[handlers]]
    [[loggers]]
        [[[""]]]  # Line 95
        [[[django]]]
        [[[celery]]]
```
When I `ConfigObj('conf.ini')` I get the error:
```
...
  File "/home/.virtualenvs/pod/lib/python3.8/site-packages/configobj.py", line 1229, in __init__
    self._load(infile, configspec)

  File "/home/.virtualenvs/pod/lib/python3.8/site-packages/configobj.py", line 1318, in _load
    raise error

  File "<string>", line unknown
NestingError: Cannot compute the section depth at line 95.
```
Is it a bug? If not, how can I define the root logger?

items.title: Fix simple typo: overidden -> overridden
items.body:
# Issue Type

[x] Bug (Typo)

# Steps to Replicate

1. Examine docs/configobj.rst.
2. Search for overidden.

# Expected Behaviour

1. Should read overridden.

items.title: problem with interpolation and logging.config.dictConfig with python3.6+
items.body:
I'm having a problem using configobj with interpolation to configure a logger. Everything works fine with python3.4, python3.5, but for python3.5 and above, I get an exception. 

Here is my test program:

```
import sys
import configobj
import logging, logging.config

msg = '***** python version: \n{}\n*****\n'.format(sys.version)
print(msg)

config = configobj.ConfigObj('logtest.ini')
# make version an int
config['logging']['version'] = int(config['logging']['version'])
logging.config.dictConfig(config['logging'])
logger=logging.getLogger('root')
logger.info(msg)

```
and my INI file:

```
[logging]
	version = 1
	level = INFO
	[[formatters]]
		[[[fmt1]]]
			format = %(asctime)s: (%(levelname)s)	%(message)s
	[[handlers]]
		[[[console]]]
			class = logging.StreamHandler
			level = INFO
			stream = ext://sys.stderr
			formatter = fmt1
		[[[file]]]
			class = logging.FileHandler
			level = INFO
			mode = a
			formatter = fmt1
			filename = test.log
	[[loggers]]
		[[[root]]]
			level = INFO
			handlers = console, file

```
running under python3.4 or python 3.5:

> (py36) C:\Users\Tim\workspace\CollectionSoftware>conda.bat activate py35
> 
> (py35) C:\Users\Tim\workspace\CollectionSoftware>python testlogging.py
> ***** python version:
> 3.5.5 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul 24 2018, 01:52:17) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
> *****
> 
> 2019-09-29 12:53:27,027: (INFO) ***** python version:
> 3.5.5 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul 24 2018, 01:52:17) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
> *****
> 
> 
But when I try the same program with python3.6, I get a ValueError when trying to configer my logger format:

> (py35) C:\Users\Tim\workspace\CollectionSoftware>conda.bat activate py36
> 
> (py36) C:\Users\Tim\workspace\CollectionSoftware>python testlogging.py
> ***** python version:
> 3.6.7 (default, Jul  2 2019, 02:21:41) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
> *****
> 
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 545, in configure
>     formatters[name])
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 327, in __getitem__
>     return self.convert_with_key(key, value)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 293, in convert_with_key
>     result = self.configurator.convert(value)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 446, in convert
>     value = ConvertingDict(value)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 557, in __getitem__
>     return self._interpolate(key, val)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 549, in _interpolate
>     return engine.interpolate(key, value)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 352, in interpolate
>     value = recursive_interpolate(key, value, self.section, {})
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 330, in recursive_interpolate
>     k, v, s = self._parse_match(match)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 417, in _parse_match
>     value, section = self._fetch(key)
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\site-packages\configobj.py", line 386, in _fetch
>     raise MissingInterpolationOption(key)
> configobj.MissingInterpolationOption: missing option "asctime" in interpolation.
> 
> During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
> 
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "testlogging.py", line 11, in <module>
>     logging.config.dictConfig(config['logging'])
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 802, in dictConfig
>     dictConfigClass(config).configure()
>   File "C:\Users\Tim\Miniconda3\envs\py36\lib\logging\config.py", line 548, in configure
>     'formatter %r: %s' % (name, e))
> ValueError: Unable to configure formatter 'fmt1': missing option "asctime" in interpolation.
> 

It could be a bug in logging.config, but I'm thinking it may be somewhere in configobj.interpolate()

Thanks for any help

items.title: How to convert strings to int?
items.body:
Let's say we write the following code into the a file called "file.config":

```
[section1]
int=5
string='hallo'
``` 

and we then parse it using configObj

config = ConfigObj('file.config')
The created dictionaly will be as follows: 
`config: {'section1': {'int':'5', 'string':'hallo'}}`

How can one convert all integer strings to int?
There is no simple example in the doc that explains it. 
I did not manage to use the validation method to do this transformation. 
is there an easy way?

items.title: Grammatical error in documentation
items.body:
https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj/blob/5b5de48a53cbceced3172bcd569ba7b2df7bfe6f/docs/configobj.html#L1900

In the section detailing how to write values over multiple lines in Unrepr mode, it says "Values that are triple quoted cased." which seems meaningless. In fact the whole paragraph is confusing.
I was trying to find out how to hand write long strings in a unrepr ConfigObj config file. """string""" and 'string' give me an error on the final line of the string.

items.title: Question: How to set parser to ignore errors?
items.body:
I am trying to edit snmptt.ini configuration file. This configuration file seems to be generated from a perl script. It also has lots of useful comments in the configuration file.


The built-in configparser works with strict option set to false.
```
import configparser
config = configparser.ConfigParser(allow_no_value=True, strict=False, interpolation=None)
config.read('/etc/snmp/snmptt.ini')
```

Is there any option in configobj to ignore errors in config file?
I am using configobj (5.0.6) on Python 3.5.2 
[snmptt.txt](https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj/files/1650549/snmptt.txt)

items.title: String interpolation using variables of other subsections
items.body:
I've been always using ConfigParser. Now that I have the need of using nested sections, I've found ConfigObj which seems to fit really my needs. The problem comes when I try to interpolate variables from other subsections. Is this possible? Otherwise the nested sections stop making sense in my case.

I have been looking for the interpolation syntax in configobj and it looks like this has not been implemented... I just wanted to be sure and to know other options to deal with this.

This is an example of what I would like to do:

```
[global]
    [[dirs]]
        software = /path-to-software-dir/
        dbs = /path-to-dbs-dir/

[A]
    [[softs]]
        soft1 = {global.dirs.software}/soft1
        soft2 = {global.dirs.software}/soft2
    [[dbs]]
        db1 = {global.dirs.dbs}/db1
        db2 = {global.dirs.dbs}/db2
```

Python: 2.7

items.title: `ConfigObj.validate()`, `preserve_errors` argument has no effect
items.body:
Hi there, seems that I'm getting dict of boolean values no matter how I use validation. 
Docs (http://configobj.readthedocs.io/en/stable/configobj.html?highlight=preserve_errors#return-value) say this:

~~~
The validate method takes an optional keyword argument preserve_errors. 
If you set this to True, instead of getting False for failed checks you get the 
actual error object from the validate module. This usually contains useful 
information about why the check failed.
~~~

I tried few slight variations of following code (validation is expected to fail and we want error message):

~~~python
# Python 2.7.12+ (default, Sep 17 2016, 12:08:02)
# Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
# 
# IPython 5.3.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
# ?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
# %quickref -> Quick reference.
# help      -> Python's own help system.
# object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.
#
# In [1]: %paste
import configobj
import validate


cfg = configobj.ConfigObj(
    infile="""
        [Section]
        foo = ZOMG!
    """.split('\n'), 
      
    configspec="""
        foo = string(min=20, max=255)
    """.split('\n'),
      
    raise_errors=True
)

cfg.validate(
    validate.Validator(), preserve_errors=True, copy=True
)


# ## -- End pasted text --
# Out[1]: {'my_foo_option': False}
# In [21]: cfg
# Out[21]: ConfigObj({'Section': {'foo': 'ZOMG!'}})
# In [22]: cfg.configspec
# Out[22]: ConfigObj({'foo': 'string(min=2, max=255)'})
~~~

items.title: RFE: Interpolating on key level
items.body:
Given that ini file:
```
[DEFAULT]
foo = 42

[s]
bar = 43
baz = %(foo)s
```

ConfigParser is able to return a value for key `foo` in section `s`:
```
print c.get('s', 'bar')  # 43
print c.get('s', 'baz')  # 42
print c.get('s', 'foo')  # 42
```

Using `ConfigObj` however, a `KeyError` is thrown:
```
print c['s']['bar']  # 43
print c['s']['baz']  # 42
print c['s']['foo']  # KeyError 'foo'
```

`ConfigParser`'s behavior is quite handy in some situations, as it allows to 'inherit' keys from a default section.

Any chance this could be implemented?

Hello,

Is there a way to copy the configobj instance? I know there there is a copy method, but it returns a `type dict`.  I want to be able to modify the copy and return its result without affecting the original object.

items.title: Lists of length 1
items.body:
When specifying in a configspec that a list can have a length of one:

testItem = list(1, 2, default=list('test','test'))

A comma has to be added in the config even while there is only one item in the list:

testItem = test,
--> works

testItem = test
--> doesn't work

This is confusing for the user of the config, especially because you don't add a comma at the end of a regular multi-item list.

items.title: Documentation of mixed_list
items.body:
There is a discrepancy in the documentation of mixed_list. In the html, it is said to work as mixed_list(str, int), while actually it is mixed_list('string', 'integer').

See https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=mixed_list
and you will see what I mean

items.title: Comment Layout Lost on Rewrite
items.body:
I use `configobj` for my project and noticed that comment layout is lost when writing the configuration file. For a trivial example, suppose you have the config file:

```
foo = bar   # My comments
answer = 42 # are lined up
```

After running the following code:

```
import configobj
configobj.ConfigObj('test.conf').write()
```

The contents of the configuration file are:

```
foo = bar# My comments
answer = 42# are lined up
```

Can preserving the formatting of config files be added as a feature to `configobj`?

items.title: Dodos (err, doc TODOs)
items.body:
- reflect validator move into submodule
- check other gaps between code and docs (when there is time; input/PRs welcome!)

items.title: Not possible to open 2+ config files into same configobj instance?
items.body:
It does not seem possible to load 2 or more files into the same configobj instance. 

In configparser, You could load multiple files into the same dictionary because it had a separate file load function, like so:

sysconf = configparser.SafeConfigParser()
sysconf.read(file1)
sysconf.read(file2)

Because configobj loads the file in it's class init, this does not seem possible for configobj in it's current state

loading multiple files is useful for when you have a large set of configuration options that have to be human readable and may need to be partially duplicated with slightly different settings for some sections 

The human readable part is why I don't move to xml, and why the nesting limitation in configparser gives me a headache.

(Granted, I just found cofigobj when searching for a solution to human readable arbitrary nesting alternatives for configparser and only skimmed the documentation, so I may have missed something that wasn't obvious.)

items.title: Validator.check('string(min=1)', v) should fail if v is None
items.body: Validating a string should fail if the value is None (at least in the cases where min >= 1). Currently it doesn't fail, but returns None (and I don't think this is documented anywhere)

items.title: _version in global namespace
items.body:
Hi,

I noticed that installing configobj puts the file `_version.py` directly into `site-packages`.
This can cause conflicts if a package has their own `_version.py` file in the `PYTHONPATH`.

items.title: PyPI tarball is missing tests directory and doesn't match github release tarball
items.body: The github v5.0.6 tar.gz release tarball contains the tests directory, but the version of the release on PyPI does not.  These two tarballs do not match.  They should be sha checksum identical, otherwise it will be unclear which is the definitive release.

items.title: Incompatible with Git-style section names
items.body:
`git config` will turn a dotted string like `branch.master.remote` into a section and key like so:

```
[branch "master"]
remote = ...
```

I was hoping to use the same style in my own application, however, while `ConfigObj` reads the above section without problem, it writes it as `['branch "master"']`. Fortunately it also reads this form, and the config file just looks ugly.

But don't run a gitconfig file through ConfigObj, or else it will break :stuck_out_tongue:

```
~/Projects/configobj$ git config --local -l
core.repositoryformatversion=0
core.filemode=true
core.bare=false
core.logallrefupdates=true
remote.origin.fetch=+refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
remote.origin.url=https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj.git
branch.master.remote=origin
branch.master.merge=refs/heads/master
~/Projects/configobj$ cat .git/config 
[core]
    repositoryformatversion = 0
    filemode = true
    bare = false
    logallrefupdates = true
[remote "origin"]
    fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
    url = https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj.git
[branch "master"]
    remote = origin
    merge = refs/heads/master
~/Projects/configobj$ python -c"from configobj import ConfigObj; c = ConfigObj('.git/config'); c.write()"
~/Projects/configobj$ cat .git/config 
[core]
    repositoryformatversion = 0
    filemode = true
    bare = false
    logallrefupdates = true
['remote "origin"']
    fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
    url = https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj.git
['branch "master"']
    remote = origin
    merge = refs/heads/master
(configobj) ~/Projects/configobj$ git config --local -l
fatal: bad config file line 6 in .git/config
~/Projects/configobj$ 
```

items.title: Unclear error message using very simple example
items.body:
``` ini
[]
a = b
[]
c = d
```

``` python
In [1]: from configobj import ConfigObj

In [2]: c = ConfigObj('./test.ini')
  File "<string>", line unknown
ConfigObjError: Parsing failed with several errors.
First error at line 1.
```

If I modify the first section name to be non-empty, the message is ok:

``` ini
[s]
a = b
[]
c = d
```

``` python
In [1]: from configobj import ConfigObj

In [2]: c = ConfigObj('./test.ini')
  File "<string>", line unknown
ParseError: Invalid line ('[]') (matched as neither section nor keyword) at line 4.
```

items.title: Move _version.py into your namespace
items.body: Currently `_version.py` is installed into `/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/_version.py` or `/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/_version.py`. There is no indication that `_version.py` belongs to configobj and could conflict with other project that do the same. So please rename _version.py to `configobj_version.py`, move it into a subdirectory, or completely get rid of it.

items.title: Please include doc and tests in pypi release
items.body:
Hi,

please include the doc and tests directory in your pypi release. This would allow Debian to use the pypi release tarball and still create the documentation and run the tests.

items.title: Values are not interpolated when converting a configobj to a dict
items.body:
I basically want to merge a custom subsection of a configobj with a dict. I tried to do:

``` python
    cfg = Configobj(config_filename, interpolation='Template')
    subsection = cfg['mysubsection']
    subsection.update(my_custom_dict)
```

But configobj does not have an 'update' method.
So, I tried to convert it to a dict:

``` python
    subsection = dict(cfg['mysubsection'])
    subsection.update(my_custom_dict)
```

The problem is that the values are not interpolated when converting a configobj or a subsection to a dict.

This issue seems to only happen to:
- subsection
- config files without any section
- the part of a config file outside any section, like 'val2' in:

"""
val1 = 12
val2 = $val1

[section1]
....
"""

I found the solution by using the 'dict' method of a configobj object:

``` python
    subsection = cfg['mysubsection'].dict()
```

but I wanted to warn you that it could be a bug.

Thank you.

items.title: Please include readme/license and possibly other files in sdist
items.body:
Hi,
would it be possible to include at least license and readme in sdist? It's really beneficial for downstream redistributors (e.g. Fedora, where I'm trying to update to latest configobj right now) to have at least these two. Adding the whole docs directory and tests would be also great - most packages do it AFAIK - but I guess it's not that necessary.
Thanks for considering.

items.title: Calling Builder.build raises a NameError
items.body:
Just run some static checkers on `configobj.py` and this issue came up. Calling `Builder.build` raises a `NameError`.

``` python
class Builder
    def build(self, o):
        if m is None:
            raise UnknownType(o.__class__.__name__)
        return m(o)

    # [omitted ]

    def build_Getattr(self, o):
        parent = self.build(o.expr)
        return getattr(parent, o.attrname)
```

This regression, if that is what it is, seems to have been introduced in (f461e506d74bddb48af27923fe3cf6ae40544a64) (Line 146).

Adding back this line should fix it:

``` python
        m = getattr(self, 'build_' + o.__class__.__name__, None)
```

Note: It seems that nor `Builder.build` neither `Build.build_Getattr` are being used anymore. At least not in `configobj.py`. Git blame shows that they exist since the initial commit. I guess that no-one is using them.

items.title: BUG? works with python 2.6, but breaks in 2.7
items.body:
On debian wheezy it works fine with python 2.6.
if i switch to 2.7 (which is default on wheezy) i get this stacktrace:

```
Unhandled exception: 'module' object has no attribute 'PY2'traceback: Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/usr/bin/diamond", line 118, in main
    config = configobj.ConfigObj(os.path.abspath(options.configfile))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/configobj.py", line 1229, in __init__
    self._load(infile, configspec)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/configobj.py", line 1287, in _load
    content = self._handle_bom(content)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/configobj.py", line 1477, in _handle_bom
    if six.PY2 and isinstance(line, str):
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'PY2'
```

```
$ python2.7 -c "import configobj; print configobj.__version__"
5.0.5
```

```
$ python2.6 -c "import configobj; print configobj.__version__"
4.7.2
```

items.title: encoding issue writing
items.body:
I am not sure if this is a bug or just my not understanding.  This is under Python 2.7, using v5.0.4 from pip.  I can't seem to write out a CfgObj that has unicode strings. Here's a simple scenario:

File: 'in.ini'

```
folder="Arbeitsfläche"
```

code:

``` python
from  configobj import ConfigObj
cfg = ConfigObj("in.ini", encoding="UTF8")

print u"folder string[{0}] and repr [{1}]".format(cfg['folder'], repr(cfg['folder']))

cfg.filename = "out.ini"
cfg.write()
```

produces this:

```
folder string[Arbeitsfläche] and repr [u'Arbeitsfl\xe4che']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "stackoverflow.py", line 7, in <module>
    cfg.write()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/configobj.py", line 2124, in write
    'ascii'))
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 18: ordinal not in range(128)
```

There doesn't seem to be any problem reading the file in.  Also, if I change the input file to have the value "Desktop" instead of "Arbeitsfläche", no problem.

What I can't understand is why it wants to use the ascii codec, when I've  explicitly set the UTF8 encoder.

Any help would be appreciated!

items.title: unit tests should typically using a config file path instead of a list of strings
items.body:
Revealed in #44, there turns out to be a difference in code paths between initializing a configobj with a string path to file, vs a list of strings representing a config file's content.

The unit tests should be refactored to _mostly_ using config file path instead of list of strings, because that's by far the most common case for our users.

items.body:
```
Exception occurred:
  File "conf.py", line 15, in <module>
    from _version import __version__
ImportError: No module named _version
```

items.title: Comments assigned to wrong sections
items.body:
This is an over-simplified version of `zypper.conf`:

```
## Configuration file for Zypper.

[main]

## Show repository alias instead of name.
# showAlias = false

## Columns to show in repository list printed by repos (lr) command by default.
# repoListColumns = Anr

[solver]

## Do not install soft dependencies (recommended packages)
# installRecommends = yes

[color]

## Whether to use colors
# useColors = never
```

When read with configobj, comments are assigned to sections in an awkward fashion:

```
>>> config = configobj.ConfigObj('zypper.conf')
>>> config.comments
{'color': ['',
  '## Do not install soft dependencies (recommended packages)',
  '# installRecommends = yes',
  ''],
 'main': [],
 'solver': ['',
  '## Show repository alias instead of name.',
  '# showAlias = false',
  '',
  '## Columns to show in repository list printed by repos (lr) command by default.',
  '# repoListColumns = Anr',
  '']}
```

As a consequence, if I run `del config['solver']` I am deleting comments of `main` and preserving comments of `solver`, leading to a very confusing configuration file:

```
--- zypper.before.conf   2014-04-06 00:20:16.432652464 +0200
+++ zypper.after.conf    2014-04-06 00:26:16.569526812 +0200
@@ -2,14 +2,6 @@

 [main]

-## Show repository alias instead of name.
-# showAlias = false
-
-## Columns to show in repository list printed by repos (lr) command by default.
-# repoListColumns = Anr
-
-[solver]
-
 ## Do not install soft dependencies (recommended packages)
 # installRecommends = yes
```

items.title: tag 5.0.3

items.title: utf8 encoded symbols not cast as unicode strings in python v2.7
items.body:
Hi!
I've been using configobj a for while in my project. Due to other dependencies
(twisted mainly), the stable release still depends on python v2.7.
Recently, an issue was opened regarding utf8 encoded symbols in the config file:
https://github.com/pazz/alot/issues/693
It turns out that this is due to configobj v5.0.x not behaving as previous versions
when it comes to utf8 encoded symbols:
Previously, those were always passed on as unicode strings, e.g. `🐜` became
u'\U0001f41c'. Now, the same symbol is read as '\xf0\x9f\x90\x9c'.
Obvously this makes trouble. Of course i can patch around this, but still,
i think configobj should behave exactly the same as prevous versions here.
Thanks!

items.title: unpin the six dependency version
items.body: at least make it `six >= 1.3.0`, we can tighten this down later if we need to

items.title: move python-coveralls dependency to travis-only
items.body:
via https://github.com/z4r/python-coveralls/issues/20
putting python-coveralls in the tox.ini file means that it's getting installed wherever the tests are run, and not just where the coveralls report is being generated. This isn't great, but it actually breaks on windows due to a dependency on [sh](http://pypi.python.org/pypi/sh) which is not compatible with windows.

items.title: Make configobj a package, moving towards incorporating validate
items.body:
Coming out of the discussion from #31, it's important to understand where we see validate fitting in long term. I think this [post](https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj/issues/31#issuecomment-36162343) does a good job of marking this out:

> 1. Make configobj a package instead of a single configobj.py file, and put validate.py inside of it. Make a separate top-level validate model that raises PendingDeprecationWarning when imported, but otherwise just works as expected. Update the documentation to tell people to do this the correct way, with a note that validate.py used to be a top-level module and is now deprecated. This step can probably come in a later 5.x release.
> 2. In a later release, keep this exactly the same, except that we'll raise DeprecationWarning instead of PendingDeprecationWarning. This would probably happen in a 6.0 release.
> 3. Remove validate.py altogether, after the deprecation warnings have been there for awhile. I'm not super concerned about this step, and IMO there should be at least a year between Step 1 and this step to give people who are not pinning their dependency versions (shame on them) time to update their code.

This is something to consider in a 5.1.x release

items.title: Include validate in the base distribution
items.body: Unless there is a compelling reason that I'm missing I would suggest that validate be merged into configobj and accordingly is moved into the configobj namespace.

items.title: Documentation of file_error confusing

milestone.description: The version check in setup.py and bugfixes if reported before tag

items.body: The documentation of the constructor param `file_error` says that it only has an effect when it is introduced in the constructor. The code doesn't use it in the constructor at all, though. Instead it is used every time [`_load()` is executed](https://github.com/DiffSK/configobj/blob/master/configobj.py#L1237).

items.title: Check Python version during installation

milestone.description: The version check in setup.py and bugfixes if reported before tag

items.body:
[Trac](http://trac.edgewall.org) uses still supports Python 2.5 on the current stable release. `easy_install ConfigObj` in a Python 2.5 environment results in an installation of ConfigObj 5.0.1 with errors. I expect we'll start seeing this issue raised on our mailing list in the near future, as we've seen for a similar circumstance of one of our other dependencies, Babel.

In Trac we do some error-checking like was is shown [here](http://trac.edgewall.org/ticket/11258#comment:12), so that an attempted installation in an unsupported Python environment will abort with a nice error message. Additionally, I don't see ConfigObj 4.7.2 being available on PyPI anymore. Is there anything additional we can do to make a Python 2.5 or earlier environment locate ConfigObj 4.7.2 and install that version?

```
$ easy_install ConfigObj
```

items.title: No unicode values when an encoding is given.

items.body:
Version 5.0.0.

If one open a utf-8 encoded file ( with filename in variable fn below ), add an encoding parameter when opening the ConfigObj, the returned object does not convert the keys and values to unicode. The version 4.7.2 did.. 

In [6]: o = ConfigObj( infile = fn , encoding = "utf8" )

In [7]: t = o["root"]["title"]

In [8]: t
Out[8]: 'Planl\xc3\xa6gning og data'

In [9]: isinstance( t , str )
Out[9]: True

In [10]: isinstance( t , unicode )
Out[10]: False

milestone.title: configobj 5.0.0 - released to pypi
milestone.description:
pushing a version 5.0.0 to pypi.python.org/configobj

This version will officially support versions:
- python 2.6
- python 2.7
- python 3.2
- python 3.3

Which notably drops support for python versions older than 2.6 (hence the major version change)

bumped release date estimate from Saturday the 9th to Wednedday, the 12th due to the dealys introduced due to Eli's laptop breaking

items.body:
In talking with Michael Foord (the original configobj creator/maintainer), he will be transferring ownership of:
- the pypi page
- the google code repo/page

and both of those should have the appropriate permissions set

This allows the current maintainers slightly easier access to making changes, and is more consistent with the python community's current expectations

items.title: tox.ini and travis.yml support for python version 2.6, 2.7, 3.2 and 3.3
items.body: configobj originally support 2.3 through 2.6 with some workarounds for 2.2. Since the goal of this project is to support python 3+, it's reasonable to re-baseline around python 2.6 as a minimum, especially since that's the earliest version that's "easy" to support on both tox and travis
